body:
Hum!! Is this on a Virtual Machine?? I just realized I'm getting the same issue only in a VM and not on a physical machine.

```
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6-preview> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0-preview.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.1.0-preview.2
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17677
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
Image from a VM:
![pscorecursor_vm_issue_2018-05-30_9-55-43](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/40724746-c84cd9f6-63ef-11e8-9479-b7b9b7f70936.jpg)

Image from my physical machine:
![img_5583](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/40725000-5f9551a8-63f0-11e8-8a99-3b216705d43e.JPG)

Physical machine.

Interestingly it seems to come back, and then go away. Going to try a few more things.

@mikemaccana 

I'm not having any problems with the cursor.  So, it maybe the video drivers issues.
I'll keep an eye on my system as I recently upgraded to the latest Windows 10 Insider.  
:)

You can check the property `[Console]::CursorVisible`, it's probably `false`, setting it to `true` should help.

Are you using `PSReadLine 2.0.0-beta1`? In that version, I started hiding the cursor while rendering to fix the flashes people see on Linux/Mac, but nobody has reported any similar issue and I've never noticed any problems.

It's not video drivers, since Powershell 5 always shows the cursor.

Weird thing is, not it's returned. Something I do in my daily workflow hides the cursor.

Net time it happens I'll run `[Console]::CursorVisible` and tell you the output.

Also @lzybkr how do I see the PSReadline version?

```
$ get-package psreadline

Name                           Version          Source                           ProviderName
----                           -------          ------                           ------------
PSReadLine                     2.0.0-beta1      https://www.powershellgallery... PowerShellGet
```

Yeah using 2.0.0-beta1. Love how powershell is so guessable. 🙂

@lzybkr 

In my case... No Beta in play!!  

PowerShell Core version:
```
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6-preview> get-Module PSReadline

ModuleType Version    Name                                ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ----                                ----------------
Script     1.2        PSReadLine                          {Get-PSReadlineKeyHandler, Get-PSReadlineOption, Remove-P...


PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6-preview> [Console]::CursorVisible
True
```
Strange!! Windows PowerShell has the same issue on my physical machine and VM as well. But no issues with PowerShell Core (except VM).

Windows PowerShell Version:  (Latest Insider ONLY):
```
PS [10] > get-Module PSReadline

ModuleType Version    Name                                ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ----                                ----------------
Script     1.2        PSReadline                          {Get-PSReadlineKeyHandler, Get-PSReadlineOption, Remove-P...


PS [17] > [Console]::CursorVisible
True
PS [19] >
```
:)
FYI .... Previous Windows Insiders version was fine!

@mikemaccana , @lzybkr 

At least in PowerShell Core, I would recommend to uninstall PSReadline (which is a pain to do), then remove/reinstall PowerShell Core.   This is to get back the non-Beta PSReadline with PowerShell Core.

This way we can truly confirm the issue.  Now, if the Beta has been installed on Windows PowerShell, then I'm not sure how fix that one.
:P

Hey @MaximoTrinidad - just wanted to respond re: uninstalling PSReadline. https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/powershell/2018/01/24/powershell-core-6-1-roadmap/ mentions:

> Some of my engineers will be spending time contributing to this project to get it to production quality so we can include it in PowerShell Core 6.0.

So I thought PSReadLine 2.0.0-beta1 was installed by Powershell 6.1 Preview 2.  Is this incorrect? I certainly don't remember installing it myself.

@mikemaccana PSCore6 still currently ships with PSReadLine 1.2 due to an issue in PSReadLine 2.0.  The issue has since been fixed, but the fix isn't available until the next PSReadLine beta release.  You would have had to manually install PSReadLine 2.0.

Thanks @SteveL-MSFT and @mikemaccana!

Just an FYI ... I create a incident in UserVoice for Windows PowerShell as the cursor has disappear from the prompt only on Virtual Machines.
@MaximoTrinidad is it Windows PowerShell specific or does it repro with cmd?  Also does it repro with PSReadLine removed?

@SteveL-MSFT,

I can repo both Windows PowerShell and PowerShell Core only on a virtual machine even without the PSReadline loaded.  

This happened after upgrading Windows 10 Insider to build 17677. 

Again, this didn't happened on the previous Windows 10 Insider.  And, it's working fine on Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.17134.48]. 

:)
@MaximoTrinidad but does it repro with cmd.exe?  We haven't made any changes in Windows PowerShell that would affect this.  It's more likely a change in Windows.
I have to say, I have notice the cursor disappearing on/off on my physical machine too. It recovers fast and is not happening all the time.

I wish I could help more - the cursor is appearing since my last reboot and I haven't been able to repro since. Going to keep an eye out for it and will tell you if I find out what behaviour causes it.

This is most likely changes happening in the Windows console.  In general, I would suggest seeing if you have the same issue with cmd.exe as that uses the same console.  I just updated to a newer build and via RDP the console cursor is gone sometimes.

Yeah! It comes and goes on my physical machine but is gone all the time on my VM. 
Well! At least someone will let the Windows Team know about it.

Thanks,
:)
@SteveL-MSFT Can you paste a link to the corresponding console issue? Thanks!
It's come back. Yeah it's in `cmd` too. What was the https://github.com/Microsoft/console/ issue number?
@mikemaccana I think it might be https://github.com/Microsoft/console/issues/193
